DOC.TEXT: Actor Christian Michael Slater was jailed Friday after he allegedly led authorities on a chase, crashed his sports car into a pole and scuffled with sheriff's deputies. Slater, 20, whose film credits include ``Heathers'' and ``Tucker,'' was booked for investigation of drunken driving, hit and run, driving with a suspended license, evading arrest, and assault on a peace officer, sheriff's Sgt. Cecil Rhambo said. Bail was set at $3,000. The actor remained in custody Friday. The chase began about 1 a.m. when a deputy saw a late-model Saab Turbo 900 traveling at more than 50 mph in a 35 mph zone, the sergeant said. When the deputy tried to stop the motorist, he sped off, made two right turns and drove into an alley, where his car slammed into a telephone pole, he said. Three passengers remained in the car while Slater got out and scaled a chain link fence, said Rhambo. When three deputies tried to arrest him, a ``small struggle'' ensued, he said. Slater also has appeared in the films ``The Name of the Rose'' and ``The Legend of Billie Jean.''

DOC.TEXT: Comedian-actor Sinbad told 100 underprivileged youths they can succeed through hard work, confidence and a good education despite the negative influences of drugs and crime that surround them. ``A lot of you may not know how much you have to offer, how important you are,'' the actor, who plays Walter on the TV series ``A Different World,'' said Thursday during a visit to the YMCA Youth Extension Center. ``I'm here to tell you you can do anything you want to. But not if you're dead or in jail.'' Sinbad, who was in town for a performance at the Midland Theater, said that speaking in black communities was a way for him to give back some of what he's learned to youngsters in need of role models. ``There's something happening in the community that is very tragic,'' he said. ``We have brothers killing brothers, right in our own neighborhood, and over what? Dope, drugs.'' He told the youths: ``I don't drink and I don't hide the fact that I don't.''

New York will get its first first lady in 12 years when Joyce Dinkins' husband David gets sworn in as mayor Jan. 1. Mrs. Dinkins, who shunned the limelight during her husband's 11-month campaign to become the first black mayor of New York, told New York Newsday in an interview published Friday, ``I haven't been newsworthy up until now.'' Mrs. Dinkins said she doesn't plan to change but predicted, ``I probably will be less private.'' She left her job as coordinator of the city office of the state Department of Taxation on Dec. 14 after 11 years at the agency. ``I thought being first lady would be a full-time job and I thought that the demands of my new career would really not allow me to work full time,'' she said. As the city's official hostess, Mrs. Dinkins, 60, will take on jobs done by Diane Coffey, chief of staff for outgoing Mayor Edward I. Koch, a bachelor.

Record-breaking football receiver Steve Largent was named by the Jaycees Friday as one of the 10 Outstanding Young Americans for 1990. The award goes to 10 Americans ages 21 through 39 who exemplify the best attributes of the nation's adults. The recepients will be honored Jan. 20 at the 52nd awards congress in Tulsa, headquarters of the U.S. Junior Chamber of Commerce. Largent, 35, was an overlooked receiver in the National Football League when he joined the Seattle Seahawks in 1976. He went on to set nearly every NFL record for receiving, including most touchdown receptions, before retiring at the end of this season. He is dedicated to community and national charities, including the Spina Bifida Foundation. The other recipients are William Webster, Missouri attorney general; Vin Weber, R-Minn.; David Cradick, a radio personality from Dallas; John Croyle of Gadsden, Ala., founder of a boy's ranch; Capt. Mario Garcia Jr. of Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, who counsels ghetto drug abusers; Cynthia Gettinger of Bradenton, Fla., who won four gold medals in the 1988 Para-Olympics; Jeff Keith of Fairfield, Conn., the first amputee to run across America; Lt. Col. Bentley Rayburn of Holloman, N.M., the youngest tactical fighter squadron commander in the U.S. Air Force; and Janni Smith of Los Angeles, founder of a health care center for paralysis patients.

Comedian Bob Hope and actress-singer Pia Zadora have joined the group of celebrities participating in this year's Rose Bowl festivities. Hope, Ms. Zadora and a host of Hollywood stars were invited to salute the University of Michigan Wolverines in the 43rd annual Big 10 dinner. Michigan, the Big 10 champion, will meet the University of Southern California, the Pac 10 leader, in the Rose Bowl football game on New Year's Day. The dinner, held Friday night, is hosted each year by the Big 10 Club of Southern California. Other celebrities set to participate in the fete include Claude Akins, Zsa Zsa Gabor, Jermaine Jackson, Tommy Lasorda, Gavin MacLeod and McLean Stevenson. Entertainment is to be provided by comedian Norm Crosby, impersonator George Kirby, Hope and Ms. Zadora. Rose Queen Yasmine Delawari and her court are scheduled to be in attendance.
